elements.content: The structure of the nanoporous metal–organic framework Cu3(BTC)2 (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) with a variety of molecular guests was studied in situ using single crystal X-ray diffraction. By collecting crystal structure data for a series of guests within the same host crystal, insights into the molecular interactions underpinning guest adsorption processes have been gained. Adsorption behaviors are influenced strongly by both enthalpic and entropic thermodynamic, as well as interpore steric (size-exclusion) effects, and we note correlations between guest attributes and these effects. Vapor adsorption measurements revealed a guest uptake capacity inversely proportional to guest size. Correspondingly, structural results show that guests reside in the smallest pores accessible to them. Interpore steric effects for larger guests cause these to be excluded from the smallest pores, and this corresponds to lower total uptake. Both hydrophilic and lipophilic small guests adsorb favorably into the 5 Å diameter smallest pore of the material, with the number of guests in these pores dependent on guest size and their location, in turn dependent upon both guest–guest interactions and competition between hydrogen-bonding interactions at the apertures of the smallest pore and lipophilic interactions at the center of the smallest pore. Hydrophilic guests with lone electron pairs interact preferentially with the coordinatively unsaturated Cu sites of the desolvated framework, with the number of these depending on steric interactions between neighboring bound guests and guest flexibility. Guest coordination at the Cu sites has a significant effect on the framework structure, increasing the Cu···Cu distance in the dinuclear unit, with the Cu3(BTC)2 unit cell being smaller when guests that do not coordinate with the Cu are present, and in the case of cyclohexane, smaller than for the desolvated framework. Overall, our comprehensive structural study reconciles Cu3(BTC)2 adsorption properties with the underlying guest–host and guest–guest interactions that gives rise to these.

elements.content: Porous metal–organic framework materials have guest–host properties that are potentially useful for many commercially important applications such as gas storage, separations, and molecular sensing. The development of analysis techniques for monitoring guest exchange in these materials is crucial for identifying potential for these applications, with studies commonly relying on measurements including gas and vapor isotherms as well as thermogravimetric analysis. Coupling the structure of these materials, as measured using diffraction, with their guest-adsorption properties, measured ex situ, has revealed important structure–function relationships, enabling the potential for targeted design.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Porous metal-organic framework materials have guest-host properties that are potentially useful for many commercially important applications such as gas storage, separations, and molecular sensing. The development of analysis techniques for monitoring guest exchange in these materials is crucial for identifying potential for these applications, with studies commonly relying on measurements including gas and vapor isotherms as well as thermogravimetric analysis. Coupling the structure of these materials, as measured using diffraction, with their guest-adsorption properties, measured ex situ, has revealed important structure-function relationships, enabling the potential for targeted design.

elements.content: Adsorptive separations can be thermodynamic, kinetic, and steric. Size exclusion (steric separation) occurs when the minimum diameter of a molecule is larger than the pore aperture and kinetic separation is based on adsorbate diffusion rate differences within the host. Both of these effects are relatively easily identified. Rate constants for adsorption are shown to follow the trend expected from the minimum guest dimensions, with the activation energies for adsorption of larger molecules higher than for smaller ones at the same loading. Thermodynamic separations can be enthalpic or entropic, with enthalpic effects occurring through adsorbate–adsorbent interaction (binding) and entropic effects arising from the degrees of freedom of the adsorbed molecule. The two thermodynamic separation mechanisms are effectively revealed through studies of the adsorbate–adsorbent crystal structure, with measurement of guests within the same host system particularly being important to understanding the adsorption behavior of porous hosts. Such studies are moving increasingly toward the in situ measurement of guests within the same host sample, for which powder diffraction approaches have received principal attention. Here we build on earlier work that pioneered the use of X-ray diffraction to follow the structure of a host in situ upon adsorption/desorption of a variety of guests within the same single crystal, by coupling this technique with information from gravimetric vapor adsorption measurements using guests adsorbed/desorbed within a single powder sample. In this way we explore the interpore steric and thermodynamic effects (both entropic and enthalpic) underpinning the adsorption behavior of a variety of guests by Cu3(BTC)2.

elements.content: Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3, BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, and also known as HKUST-1, is a metal–organic framework with a Pt3O4-type network that is cubic (Fm3̅m) and composed of dinuclear cupric tetracarboxylate units bridged by three-connecting BTC linkers. Complete dehydration of the material to Cu3(BTC)2 can be achieved, creating a material with coordinatively unsaturated Cu atoms. Cu3(BTC)2 has a three-dimensional channel system consisting of pores of three different sizes. Cuboctahedral pores are formed from 12 dinuclear Cu2(carboxylate)4 “paddlewheel” subunits, featuring a distance across the pore center of approximately 10.7 Å (distance between Cu atoms of opposite dinuclear units), centered at the unit cell center and midpoints of the unit cell edges. This pore has benzene linker units surrounding it face-on, with the Cu–Cu vectors of the dinuclear unit parallel to its surface, and is termed “aromatic” or Pore A, shown in Figure . Pore A is connected to a second, larger pore system, Pore B, centered on the faces and corners of the unit cell with a distance across the pore center of approximately 12.7 Å (distance between Cu atoms of opposite dinuclear units). Pore B is defined by edge-on BTC units with Cu–Cu vectors pointing toward the pore center. These pores are connected via triangular windows to the smallest pores, Pore C, in which four benzene rings constitute the inner surface with the ring centers forming a tetrahedron approximately 5 Å in diameter. The BTC units make Pore C inaccessible from Pore A. Pore A is surrounded by six Pore Bs and Pore B is surrounded by eight Pore Cs.

elements.content: Cu3(BTC)2 is electrically neutral, but local variations in charge exist where the Cu centers maintain a positive charge with the remaining negative charge distributed over the BTC unit. Nonspecific van der Waals interactions with species may prevail, which could be superimposed by specific coulomb-type electrostatic interactions, subject to the properties of the adsorbing species. The CuII ion of the framework and the partial negative charge on the carboxylate groups behave as a surface ion pair. Evidence exists for two types of CuII ions in Cu3(BTC)2: the majority framework CuII and a second more polarizing but less populated CuII site, attributed to paramagnetic cupric ions in the pores. The framework CuII ions are antiferromagnetically coupled within the dinuclear paddlewheel units.

elements.content: The features of Cu3(BTC)2, described above, allow guest species to be incorporated into this material, many reversibly, making the material a good candidate for separations, catalysis, sensing, and gas storage, and there has been a surge of interest in this material for these purposes. The material also conducts protons, with guest species controlling to a large degree the proton conductivity. Several force-fields were developed for Cu3(BTC)2, facilitating the understanding of guest–host functionality in the material computationally.

Several force-fields were developed for Cu3(BTC)2, facilitating the understanding of guest-host functionality in the material computationally.

elements.content: Cu3(BTC)2 can separate a wide-range of mixtures, such as polar and nonpolar guests where electron-rich molecules are removed, including amines and ammonia, water traces, alcohols, and oxygenates. The material has a strong preference for carbon dioxide over methane, and for carbon dioxide over dinitrogen, methane over dinitrogen, as well as for both nitrous oxide and carbon dioxide over dinitrogen and dioxygen. A high selectivity is noted for carbon tetrachloride over the different components of air. Cu3(BTC)2 has a strong preference for unsaturated over saturated hydrocarbons, preferring vinyltoluene to ethyltoluene and styrene to ethylbenzene, the latter being an industrially important separation where Cu3(BTC)2 can separate an ethylbenzene/styrene mixture with a separation factor as high as 5.5. Similarly, isobutene and isobutane can be separated by the material, which has a preference for ethene over ethane, octene over octane, and p-xylene to 1-octene.

elements.content: Enthalpic effects play a major role in controlling the guest selectivity and uptake of Cu3(BTC)2. Most importantly, a guest possessing a dipole moment can bind with the coordinatively unsaturated Cu sites, with these sites thought to facilitate the high uptake of guests that include nitric oxide, ethyne, and carbon dioxide. The working capacity of this material for carbon dioxide exceeds that of the benchmark zeolite 13× 4-fold over the same pressure range. The mechanism of guest binding with the Cu sites varies, with the interaction of carbon dioxide, as well as both carbon monoxide and dinitrogen, at the Cu sites occurring through a linear adsorption, as distinct from the configuration observed for dihydrogen and ethyne. The relatively short distance of dihydrogen from the Cu atom (2.39(1) Å) indicates a significant interaction with the d9 Cu­(II) center, although not as significant as that of σ-bonded η2-dihydrogen complexes. This interaction is consistent with the high energy ν­(H–H) sideband in the infrared spectrum of dihydrogen loaded Cu3(BTC)2, shown to arise from the dihydrogen quadrapole and not along the direction of the dinuclear Cu units. Dihydrogen experiences a large perturbation on adsorbing to the Cu site, as found using variable temperature infrared spectroscopy, a result correlated with the adsorption enthalpy. Combined inelastic neutron scattering and first-principles models indicated no elongation of the H–H bond for dihydrogen adsorbed at the Cu site. The preferential adsorption of unsaturated over saturated alkanes by Cu3(BTC)2 is thought to arise from specific interactions between guest π-electrons and the partial positive charges on the framework Cu. Although the first observation of a Cu­(II) carbonyl complex within a crystalline microporous material was made in a study of carbon monoxide in Cu3(BTC)2, the lower absorbance of carbon monoxide over carbon dioxide is attributed to the absence of significant interactions with the Cu or π–π type interactions.

elements.content: Entropic effects compete with enthalpic effects to dictate guest adsorption and separation by Cu3(BTC)2, which is known to depend on the size, shape, and dipole moment of the molecule. A concentration-dependent guest location in Cu3(BTC)2 is found, including for ethyne, dihydrogen, methane, and carbon dioxide, with molecules preferentially adsorbing onto the Cu site, then progressively into small, followed by larger, pores. Similarly, there is a preference for the adsorption of smaller alkanes into smaller “side pocket” sites at low loadings, whereas guests such as isobutene are excluded from these smaller pockets. Molecular deuterium has ten distinct binding sites in Cu3(BTC)2, with six stable and the remainder metastable at gas loadings intermediate to saturation. The sites preferable for dihydrogen were found to be similar to those for ethyne, methane, and carbon dioxide guests. Four adsorption sites have been noted for both quadrapolar and nonpolar gaseous guests, with a site located at the window between Pores C and B noted to be favorable for dihydrogen, dinitrogen, methane, and carbon monoxide, as well as argon gas. The adsorption of alkanes is also found to occur preferentially in regions close to this “window” site.

elements.content: While kinetic separation effects are noted in Cu3(BTC)2 through differences in the diffusion of linear and branched alkanes, such effects are complicated by the host flexibility, as found by molecular dynamics simulations and infrared microscopy where the incorporation of lattice flexibility affected the simulated guest diffusivities. Cu3(BTC)2 is both flexible and compressible, with the size and shape of pores and connecting apertures varying as a function of guest concentration, resulting in a significant correlation between framework response and guest uptake. It is the lattice response to guest adsorption that is useful for chemical sensing, through distortions of the structure.

It is the lattice response to guest adsorption that is useful for chemical sensing, through distortions of the structure.

elements.content: Guest inclusion can have a profound effect on Cu3(BTC)2 behavior. For chemical sensing applications, detection selectivity can be controlled through the hydration state of the Cu sites. Cu3(BTC)2 also has catalytic properties, where the Cu acts as a hard Lewis acid. For catalytic applications, the yield of a reaction catalyzed, as well as the product selectivity and percentage conversion, can be influenced by the choice of solvent. This application requires knowledge of solvent interactions in Cu3(BTC)2, which has the following order of solvent preference: toluene > acetonitrile > methanol > 1,2-dichloroethane > ethyl ethanoate. Interestingly, a high efficiency for conversion of the ortho to para dihydrogen by Cu3(BTC)2 is found, and modification to host Keggin polyoxometalates created a solid heterogeneous acid catalyst, further demonstrating the importance of understanding guest–host interactions in the material.

elements.content: The current work characterizes structurally a series of molecular guests in Cu3(BTC)2, as well as the framework response to guest adsorption, using single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD). The quantity of adsorbed guest is estimated through both electron density difference calculations and gravimetric adsorption measurements. In this way, detailed insights into the mechanisms underpinning adsorption behavior and selectivity of Cu3(BTC)2 are gained, particularly entropic and enthalpic thermodynamic, and size-exclusion, effects.

elements.content: All chemicals were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich at 99% purity. Liquid guests for vapor adsorption were purified overnight with molecular sieves and calcium chloride. Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3·xH2O was synthesized by the addition of 0.700 mol of Cu­(NO3)2·6H2O in 6 mL of H2O to 0.03510 mol of H3BTC dispersed by sonication in 6 mL of ethanol. The mixture was stirred for 20 min, transferred into a 20 mL Teflon insert, placed in a Parr solvothermal bomb and heated to 95 °C for 18 h, and then cooled to room temperature over 8 h. Blue crystals were obtained by filtering, washing with deionized water, and air-drying. A single crystal was isolated for the SCXRD experiments. The remaining crystals were separated from a secondary product by alternative washing and sonication in methanol, a process involving four repeats with two washes performed at 50 °C. The product of pure blue crystals was air-dried and used for gravimetric vapor adsorption measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Preparation of Cu3(BTC)2 and Guests

All chemicals were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich at 99% purity. Liquid guests for vapor adsorption were purified overnight with molecular sieves and calcium chloride. Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3⋅xH2O was synthesized by the addition of 0.700 mol of Cu(NO3)2⋅6H2O in 6 mL of H2O to 0.03510 mol of H3BTC dispersed by sonication in 6 mL of ethanol. The mixture was stirred for 20 min, transferred into a 20 mL Teflon insert, placed in a Parr solvothermal bomb and heated to 95 °C for 18 h, and then cooled to room temperature over 8 h. Blue crystals were obtained by filtering, washing with deionized water, and air-drying. A single crystal was isolated for the SCXRD experiments. The remaining crystals were separated from a secondary product by alternative washing and sonication in methanol, a process involving four repeats with two washes performed at 50 °C. The product of pure blue crystals was air-dried and used for gravimetric vapor adsorption measurements.

elements.content: Data were collected on a Bruker-Nonius APEX II-FR591 diffractometer fitted with an Oxford Cryosystems Series 700 nitrogen Cryostream. A crystal was mounted in a polyimide capillary with the top end open in the center of the nitrogen cryostream and the bottom end open and either connected to a tube to allow dry helium or helium/vapor flow, or closed using a metal seal. Each data set was collected at a detector-sample distance of 50.2 mm, with six scans at 2θ = −28.8°, two ω positions at −15° and 40°, for three φ angles at 0°, 120°, and 240°, and at the two χ positions, 54.7 and −54.7°. The first data set was collected at 20 °C after 8 h in helium flow where a small residual fraction of bound water was found at the highly hygroscopic Cu site, attributable to a small degree of air back-flow in the capillary. This data set was used to determine the equilibrium hydration achieved using this setup, necessary for understanding water present as an impurity in other data sets, and all references to water in this system are in reference to this data set. The crystal was then heated to 200 °C at 360 °C h–1 under dry helium flow and left at 200 °C for 30 min. After 30 min, the helium flow was replaced with the metal seal, the crystal was cooled at 360 °C h–1 to 20 °C, and the data set for the desolvated framework was collected. After the desolvated framework data set and between data sets for different vapors the sample was heated to 200 °C at 360 °C h–1 under helium flow and left at 200 °C for 30 min. After this time, the helium flow was replaced with the chosen vapor flow, obtained by bubbling helium through a glass vial of the selected guest liquid. After 30 min of exposure to vapor flow, the crystal was cooled at 360 °C h–1 to 20 °C and left for 10 min, after which the tubing was replaced with the seal and a data set collected. Full data sets were collected for the following adsorptives: cyclohexane, hexane, methanol (MeOH), ethanol (EtOH), 1-propanol (1-PrOH), 2-propanol (2-PrOH), toluene, acetonitrile (MeCN), and tetrahydrofuran (THF). The diffraction data were reduced with SAINT+ version 6.02.3. Lorentz, polarization, and empirical absorption corrections were applied to all data using SADABS. The structures were solved and refined with SHELXTL-97 using the WinGX graphical user interface. In the SCXRD data models, hydrogen atoms were placed at calculated positions on the benzene linker units and on the coordinated H2O, MeOH, THF, and MeCN. In cases of partial guest occupancy, the site occupation was refined while fixing a known or reasonable atomic displacement parameter (ADP), and, for bound MeCN, 1-PrOH, and 2-PrOH, subsequently constrained to the determined fraction with refinement of ADPs. Crystallographic information framework (CIF) files are given in the . The contribution to SCXRD data by uncoordinated guests was estimated using PLATON/SQUEEZE, as executed on the framework model with the largest of any coordinated molecules remaining. This estimation assumes 100% occupation of coordinated guests. By using PLATON/SOLV the solvent-accessible void volumes were estimated using a probe radius of 1.2 Å. Fourier-difference analyses revealed the location of guests. MarchingCubes 3D Fourier contour electron density map display software was used to visualize the extra-framework residual electron density.

After this time, the helium flow was replaced with the chosen vapor flow, obtained by bubbling helium through a glass vial of the selected guest liquid. After 30 min of exposure to vapor flow, the crystal was cooled at 360 °C h-1 to 20 °C and left for 10 min, after which the tubing was replaced with the seal and a data set collected. Full data sets were collected for the following adsorptives: cyclohexane, hexane, methanol (MeOH), ethanol (EtOH), 1-propanol (1-PrOH), 2-propanol (2-PrOH), toluene, acetonitrile (MeCN), and tetrahydrofuran (THF). The diffraction data were reduced with SAINT+ version 6.02.3. Lorentz, polarization, and empirical absorption corrections were applied to all data using SADABS. The structures were solved and refined with SHELXTL-97 using the WinGX graphical user interface. In the SCXRD data models, hydrogen atoms were placed at calculated positions on the benzene linker units and on the coordinated H2O, MeOH, THF, and MeCN. In cases of partial guest occupancy, the site occupation was refined while fixing a known or reasonable atomic displacement parameter (ADP), and, for bound MeCN, 1-PrOH, and 2-PrOH, subsequently constrained to the determined fraction with refinement of ADPs. Crystallographic information framework (CIF) files are given in the . The contribution to SCXRD data by uncoordinated guests was estimated using PLATON/SQUEEZE, as executed on the framework model with the largest of any coordinated molecules remaining. This estimation assumes 100% occupation of coordinated guests. By using PLATON/SOLV the solvent-accessible void volumes were estimated using a probe radius of 1.2 Å. Fourier-difference analyses revealed the location of guests. MarchingCubes 3D Fourier contour electron density map display software was used to visualize the extra-framework residual electron density.

elements.content: Gravimetric vapor adsorption experiments were performed using an IGA-002 from Hiden Isochema. Approximately 84 mg of powder Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3·x(H2O) was heated to 200 °C under vacuum (<10–5 mbar) for 9 h (forming Cu3(BTC)2) and cooled to 30 °C. Vapor adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured at 30 °C for MeOH, EtOH, 1-PrOH, 2-PrOH, benzene, cyclohexane, toluene, and methylcyclohexane at pressures up to 0.9 of saturation pressure (P 0). At each pressure the sample weight was monitored until equilibrium mass was achieved, or, in the case of cyclohexane, for 90 min. Reported masses are corrected for buoyancy of the sample and the balance. Adsorption isotherms of THF and MeCN were not measured because of incompatibility with the seals on the instrument.
elements.clean_text:
Vapor Adsorption Isotherms

Gravimetric vapor adsorption experiments were performed using an IGA-002 from Hiden Isochema. Approximately 84 mg of powder Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3⋅x(H2O) was heated to 200 °C under vacuum (<10-5 mbar) for 9 h (forming Cu3(BTC)2) and cooled to 30 °C. Vapor adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured at 30 °C for MeOH, EtOH, 1-PrOH, 2-PrOH, benzene, cyclohexane, toluene, and methylcyclohexane at pressures up to 0.9 of saturation pressure (P 0). At each pressure the sample weight was monitored until equilibrium mass was achieved, or, in the case of cyclohexane, for 90 min. Reported masses are corrected for buoyancy of the sample and the balance. Adsorption isotherms of THF and MeCN were not measured because of incompatibility with the seals on the instrument.

elements.content: We consider guest location and orientation and present residual electron density maps obtained by subtracting electron density of the Cu3(BTC)2 framework from each of the guest-sorbed data sets. From these maps, four guest locations were identified in the Fm3̅m structure: site 1 at the Cu sites (Wyckoff letter h, 2mm (C 2v ) symmetry, 3 per formula unit); site 2 at the center of the window accessing Pore C from the largest Pore B (Wyckoff letter f, 3m (C 3v ) symmetry, 2 per formula unit); site 3 at the center of Pore C (Wyckoff letter c, 43m (T d ) symmetry, 0.5 per formula unit); and site 4 in the large aromatic Pore A near the window connecting Pores A and B (Wyckoff letter e, 4mm (C 4v ) symmetry, 1.5 per formula unit). These sites coincide with those identified previously for D2, CD4, and CO2.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

We consider guest location and orientation and present residual electron density maps obtained by subtracting electron density of the Cu3(BTC)2 framework from each of the guest-sorbed data sets. From these maps, four guest locations were identified in the Fm3̅m structure: site 1 at the Cu sites (Wyckoff letter h, 2mm (C 2v ) symmetry, 3 per formula unit); site 2 at the center of the window accessing Pore C from the largest Pore B (Wyckoff letter f, 3m (C 3v ) symmetry, 2 per formula unit); site 3 at the center of Pore C (Wyckoff letter c, 43m (T  d ) symmetry, 0.5 per formula unit); and site 4 in the large aromatic Pore A near the window connecting Pores A and B (Wyckoff letter e, 4mm (C 4v ) symmetry, 1.5 per formula unit). These sites coincide with those identified previously for D2, CD4, and CO2.

elements.content:
Of the guests investigated, the alcohols (MeOH, EtOH, 1-PrOH, and 2-PrOH), THF, and MeCN each coordinate to the bare Cu atoms (site 1) of the framework (see Figure and Table ).

Because of the close proximity of site 1 to its immediate neighbors (Cu···Cu = ∼8 Å) and its alignment toward the interior of the Pore B (Figure , right), the fractional guest binding at this site varies depending on the extent of steric interactions between neighboring bound guests, and some occluded Cu sites were occupied by the much smaller H2O guest, which was present in the capillary as a vapor impurity due to air back-flow. Full site occupancy is achieved by the smaller, rotationally flexible guests THF, MeOH, and EtOH. Each of these is disordered locally over two equivalent sites, as shown in Figure . THF is oriented such that its butyl group projects toward the center of the square faces of the Cu12 cuboctahedra of Pore B; in this arrangement each square pore window (see Figure , right) is occupied by two bound THF guests. In contrast, MeOH and EtOH orient such that their alkyl groups point toward the center of the triangular faces of the Cu cuboctahedra. In this arrangement, four of these triangular faces contain the alkyl groups of two guests and four contain one, and for EtOH, steric clash of the ethyl groups is avoided by approximately 1/3 of these pointing into the pore.
elements.clean_text:
Coordinating Guests: Interaction at the Cu Site

Of the guests investigated, the alcohols (MeOH, EtOH, 1-PrOH, and 2-PrOH), THF, and MeCN each coordinate to the bare Cu atoms (site 1) of the framework (see Figure  and Table ).

Because of the close proximity of site 1 to its immediate neighbors (Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu = ~8 Å) and its alignment toward the interior of the Pore B (Figure , right), the fractional guest binding at this site varies depending on the extent of steric interactions between neighboring bound guests, and some occluded Cu sites were occupied by the much smaller H2O guest, which was present in the capillary as a vapor impurity due to air back-flow. Full site occupancy is achieved by the smaller, rotationally flexible guests THF, MeOH, and EtOH. Each of these is disordered locally over two equivalent sites, as shown in Figure . THF is oriented such that its butyl group projects toward the center of the square faces of the Cu12 cuboctahedra of Pore B; in this arrangement each square pore window (see Figure , right) is occupied by two bound THF guests. In contrast, MeOH and EtOH orient such that their alkyl groups point toward the center of the triangular faces of the Cu cuboctahedra. In this arrangement, four of these triangular faces contain the alkyl groups of two guests and four contain one, and for EtOH, steric clash of the ethyl groups is avoided by approximately 1/3 of these pointing into the pore.

Note: Superposition of the donor atom sites for the guest and H2O ligands led to high correlation between occupancy and atomic displacement parameters. For the 1-PrOH and 2-PrOH phases, the H2O occupancy was fixed at 1/3 whereas it was allowed to refine for MeCN.

The larger alcohols 1-PrOH and 2-PrOH were found to bind at only 2/3 of the Cu sites, again disordered over multiple sites (Figure ), and this stoichiometry appears to arise from the fact that there is space only for one guest at each of the 8 triangular faces of the Cu cuboctahedra due to steric clashes of the bulkier alkyl groups of these larger alcohols. In the case of MeCN sorption, only 1/3 of the Cu sites were found to be occupied, as a result of the steric requirement that neighboring Cu sites cannot be occupied simultaneously due to clashes of the methyl groups (crystallographic Me···Me = 3.39 Å; see Figure ) of this linearly binding guest. The 4 of 12 bound Cu sites of Pore B are therefore likely to be arranged locally as a tetrahedron and/or as a square, and notably, the former arrangement breaks the crystallographic mm2 site 1 symmetry, leading to the local displacement of the guest from its ideal linear binding orientation, consistent with the large displacement parameter refined for the MeCN methyl group. The symmetry of the site for CD4 was previously noted to be incompatible with the Cu3(BTC)2 symmetry.

elements.content: While accurate determination of the location and alignment of bound guests was aided by the localizing influence of the Cu atom, the crystallographic modeling of unbound guests proved more challenging. We attribute this both to the dynamic nature of these guests, leading to large atomic displacement parameters, and to the fact that their molecular symmetries were in most cases lower than the crystallographic site symmetries, leading to partial atom site occupancies; these influences are evident in the smeared pore electron-densities shown in Figure . From these residual density maps it is evident that MeOH and EtOH dock in each of the four window sites (site 2) of Pore C, with only a very small amount of electron density observed in the center of the pore (site 3), and there remains some residual electron density at site 4. In contrast, the larger alcohols 1-PrOH and 2-PrOH, and THF, adsorb in the center of Pore C (site 3), with no residual electron density evident at site 2, and again some electron density is seen at site 4, which is particularly pronounced for THF. MeCN and hexane reside in Pore C with electron density for both in the pore center (site 3) and toward the windows (site 2). In contrast, cyclohexane and toluene, which are too large to fit into Pore C, reside at site 4, as evidenced by the rings of electron density seen in Figures j and k, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Noncoordinating Guests: Interaction within the Pores

While accurate determination of the location and alignment of bound guests was aided by the localizing influence of the Cu atom, the crystallographic modeling of unbound guests proved more challenging. We attribute this both to the dynamic nature of these guests, leading to large atomic displacement parameters, and to the fact that their molecular symmetries were in most cases lower than the crystallographic site symmetries, leading to partial atom site occupancies; these influences are evident in the smeared pore electron-densities shown in Figure . From these residual density maps it is evident that MeOH and EtOH dock in each of the four window sites (site 2) of Pore C, with only a very small amount of electron density observed in the center of the pore (site 3), and there remains some residual electron density at site 4. In contrast, the larger alcohols 1-PrOH and 2-PrOH, and THF, adsorb in the center of Pore C (site 3), with no residual electron density evident at site 2, and again some electron density is seen at site 4, which is particularly pronounced for THF. MeCN and hexane reside in Pore C with electron density for both in the pore center (site 3) and toward the windows (site 2). In contrast, cyclohexane and toluene, which are too large to fit into Pore C, reside at site 4, as evidenced by the rings of electron density seen in Figures j and k, respectively.

elements.content: Despite guest disorder, modeling and refinement allowed the determination of the location and some orientation detail for the various guests. In examining first the location of the alcohol guests, we see a distinct size-dependent effect. Four MeOH and EtOH guests bind at each of the windows of Pore C (3-fold disorder at site 2) to form two equivalent hydrogen bonding interactions with their Cu-bound neighbors (Figure a and b, O···O = 3.24 and 3.26 Å for MeOH and EtOH, respectively). In contrast, only a single molecule of the larger alcohols, 1-PrOH and 2-PrOH, fit inside Pore C, lying closer to its center at site 3. Of these, 1-PrOH extends toward site 2 with 4-fold positional disorder to form a hydrogen bonding interaction with the BTC carboxylate groups (Figure c, with modeling on the 3-fold axis yielding six equivalent O···O distances of 3.90 Å). Disorder of the 2-PrOH, at the T d -symmetry pore center, prevented full refinement of atom locations.

elements.content: Adsorbed MeCN is relatively highly ordered (Figure d) and we note that Pore C contains four MeCN molecules such that one of the four lies toward the center (site 3) while the remaining three reside within the pore windows (site 2) and hydrogen bond to the MeCN methyl group of the former, with this tetrameric hydrogen-bonded unit disordered over the 4 possible orientations. A similar situation is seen for hexane, for which a single guest extends between sites 2 and 3 (Figure e). The lower symmetry and flexible nature of this guest leads to a higher degree of crystallographic disorder relative to the MeCN guest (requiring 3-fold axial constraint of the atom positions for a stable refinement), with modeling of this unit giving 24 equiv orientations within the pore. Modeling of the cyclic guests cyclohexane and toluene led to accurate location of these at the center of the square windows of Pore A (site 4, see Figure ). We find steric selectivity within the pore Cu3(BTC)2 topology, with a clear size effect for these guests and no evidence for their adsorption into Pore C due to their size-exclusion, with the triangular window diameter = 5.2 Å (Cu···Cu distance minus van der Waals radius) cf. diameters of cyclohexane and toluene of ∼6.6 Å. Disorder of each about the 4mm (C 4v ) axis at site 4 prevented location or modeling of the hydrogen atoms. Despite this rotational disorder, the molecules themselves are remarkably localized in orientation, and both the boat and chair configuration of the cyclohexane molecule could be modeled (boat configuration shown in Figure , right). We attribute this well-defined localization to the slanted edge-to-face interaction of each guest with the aromatic π-clouds of four neighboring BTC units; C­(guest)···C­(BTC) = ∼3.85 and 3.93 Å for toluene and cyclohexane, respectively, with corresponding distances from the guest centroids to the Cu atoms of 6.25 and 6.57 Å. Due perhaps largely to the differences in guest shape and their influence on these interactions, we find that the buckled cyclohexane guest achieves a more efficient packing within the pore than does the planar toluene guest, with the distance of the toluene and cyclohexane guests from the centroid to the center of Pore A being 4.86 and 4.24 Å, respectively, with intermolecular guest C···C distances of 5.22 and 3.93 Å.

elements.content: Overall, we see adsorption behaviors that are influenced strongly by thermodynamic effects (both enthalpic and entropic), as well as interpore steric (size-exclusion) effects. As expected, hydrophilic guests with lone electron pairs interact preferentially at the bare Cu atoms (site 1) lining the surface of Pore B, with the number of these depending on steric interactions between neighboring bound guests. Small guests, both hydrophilic and lipophilic in nature, are adsorbed favorably into the 5 Å diameter Pore C, with their number and location depending on both guest–guest interactions and competition between the enthalpic effects of hydrogen-bonding interactions at site 2 and lipophilic interactions at site 3.

Key distances for Pores A and C in Cu3(BTC)2. Shown are (i) Cu···Cu intradimer (red), (ii) Cu···Cu across Pore C (blue), (iii) Cu···Cu across Pore A (purple), (iv) Cu···Cu distance in Pore A via BTC (pink), (v) BTC centroid···centroid across Pore A (orange), and (vi) BTC centroid···centroid across Pore C (green).

elements.content: The Cu···Cu distance in the dinuclear unit (i, Figure ), which is 2.490(1) Å in the desolvated framework, increases as guests are included in the following (increasing distance) order: H2O < cyclohexane ≈ toluene < THF < hexane <1-PrOH ≈ 2-PrOH = EtOH < MeOH < MeCN. We find that the length of the dinuclear unit is at least ∼1.2% longer with any guest species present. This finding is consistent with a shortening of the Cu···Cu distance and distortion of the Cu···O bond upon dehydration from Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3 to Cu3(BTC)2.
elements.clean_text: The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance in the dinuclear unit (i, Figure ), which is 2.490(1) Å in the desolvated framework, increases as guests are included in the following (increasing distance) order: H2O < cyclohexane ~ toluene < THF < hexane <1-PrOH ~ 2-PrOH = EtOH < MeOH < MeCN. We find that the length of the dinuclear unit is at least ~1.2% longer with any guest species present. This finding is consistent with a shortening of the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance and distortion of the Cu⋅⋅⋅O bond upon dehydration from Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3 to Cu3(BTC)2.

elements.content: The Cu···Cu separation across Pore C (ii, Figure ) increases in the following order of guest inclusion: cyclohexane < desolvated < hexane < toluene < H2O < 1-PrOH ≈ 2-PrOH ≈ EtOH < MeOH < MeCN < THF. The Cu···Cu separation across Pore A (iii, Figure ) increases with almost the same order of guest inclusion as the increase in the distance across Pore C (ii, Figure ): cyclohexane < desolvated < hexane < toluene < H2O < 2-PrOH < 1-PrOH < EtOH < MeOH < MeCN < THF. In general, adsorption of noncoordinating guests results in smaller distances across Pores A and C compared to adsorption of the coordinating guests, despite the coordination of some H2O at the Cu site in the former case.
elements.clean_text: The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separation across Pore C (ii, Figure ) increases in the following order of guest inclusion: cyclohexane < desolvated < hexane < toluene < H2O < 1-PrOH ~ 2-PrOH ~ EtOH < MeOH < MeCN < THF. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separation across Pore A (iii, Figure ) increases with almost the same order of guest inclusion as the increase in the distance across Pore C (ii, Figure ): cyclohexane < desolvated < hexane < toluene < H2O < 2-PrOH < 1-PrOH < EtOH < MeOH < MeCN < THF. In general, adsorption of noncoordinating guests results in smaller distances across Pores A and C compared to adsorption of the coordinating guests, despite the coordination of some H2O at the Cu site in the former case.

elements.content: A change in the lattice parameter was noted with guest adsorption, increasing in the same order as the Cu···Cu distance across Pore A. The lattice parameter of the desolvated framework is 26.2711(4) Å, while the lattice parameter is at least 26.3 Å with coordinating guests, where coordination of the molecules MeCN and THF result in significant increases in the lattice parameter compared to the desolvated framework. For noncoordinating guests a less marked effect is observed, with adsorption of toluene and hexane giving lattice parameters of 26.3011(5) and 26.2843(17) Å, respectively, and adsorption of cyclohexane reducing the lattice parameter to 26.2498(4) Å. A similar phenomenon was noted previously upon adsorption of dideuterium at low loadings into the sample where the lattice parameter increased initially before contracting slightly at intermediate guest loadings. This contraction is associated with a subtle buckling of the BTC units and a concomitant decrease in the BTC bridged Cu···Cu distance across Pore A (iv, Figure ) from 8.07(1) Å to 8.03(1) Å. Here, adsorption of cyclohexane results in a Cu···Cu distance of 8.0007(9) Å across the BTC unit in Pore A, which is significantly smaller than the 8.0433(3) Å in the bare framework. This reduction is associated with a decrease in the distance across Pore A between the centroids of the benzene units (v, Figure ) from 14.2806(2) Å (desolvated) to 14.1418(2) Å upon cyclohexane sorption, the largest induced by any of the guests investigated here.

elements.content: The distance across the BTC bridged Cu···Cu (iv, Figure ) increases in the following order of guests: hexane < MeCN ≈ cyclohexane <2-PrOH ≈ MeOH ≈ 1-PrOH < EtOH < toluene < THF < water < desolvated. In Pore A, the distance between the centroids of the two benzene rings across the pore (v, Figure ) increases with the following guest order: cyclohexane < hexane <1-PrOH < EtOH < THF < 2-PrOH < MeOH ≈ MeCN < desolvated < H2O < toluene. In Pore C, the distance between the centroids of the two nearest benzene units (vi, Figure ) across the pore increases in the following guest order: desolvated < toluene < H2O < MeOH < 2-PrOH < MeCN < EtOH < 1-PrOH < THF < cyclohexane < hexane.

In Pore A, the distance between the centroids of the two benzene rings across the pore (v, Figure ) increases with the following guest order: cyclohexane < hexane <1-PrOH < EtOH < THF < 2-PrOH < MeOH ~ MeCN < desolvated < H2O < toluene. In Pore C, the distance between the centroids of the two nearest benzene units (vi, Figure ) across the pore increases in the following guest order: desolvated < toluene < H2O < MeOH < 2-PrOH < MeCN < EtOH < 1-PrOH < THF < cyclohexane < hexane.

elements.content: Given the strong dideuterium concentration dependency of the structural response of Cu3(BTC)2, we hypothesize that the structural response upon guest adsorption in this study will differ for low and high guest concentrations. The total number of guest molecules is estimated from the sum of the number of coordinated guests, obtained from the SCXRD data, and the number of noncoordinated guests, obtained using the SQUEEZE utility in PLATON (Table ). The number of noncoordinated guests per Cu3(BTC)2 unit was estimated assuming all nonframework electron density arises from the introduced guests and ignores water impurities.
elements.clean_text:
Quantity of Adsorbed Guests Measured Using Diffraction

Given the strong dideuterium concentration dependency of the structural response of Cu3(BTC)2, we hypothesize that the structural response upon guest adsorption in this study will differ for low and high guest concentrations. The total number of guest molecules is estimated from the sum of the number of coordinated guests, obtained from the SCXRD data, and the number of noncoordinated guests, obtained using the SQUEEZE utility in PLATON (Table ). The number of noncoordinated guests per Cu3(BTC)2 unit was estimated assuming all nonframework electron density arises from the introduced guests and ignores water impurities.

elements.content: In the cases of cyclohexane and H2O, the SQUEEZE utility finds no uncoordinated guest molecules. Removal of some coordinated H2O likely occurred as the SCXRD data for Cu3(BTC)2 with H2O were collected on the “as made” crystal and not after saturation with the guest vapor, so it is reasonable that no pore H2O molecules would be present.

SCXRD data, accounting for both coordinated and noncoordinated guests (total guests, Table ), results in the following order of adsorption quantities: MeCN > MeOH > EtOH > 1-PrOH ≈ THF > 2-PrOH > hexane > toluene > cyclohexane. Coordinating guests are included in larger quantities in Cu3(BTC)2 than noncoordinating guests. More of the MeCN and the smaller alcohol guests are adsorbed than the larger alcohol and THF guests, indicating an effect of molecular size for these coordinating guests. Previous work used the conversion rate of α-pinene oxide to campholenic acid to indirectly deduce the following adsorption order of guests in Cu3(BTC)2: Toluene > MeCN > MeOH > 1,2-dichloroethane > ethyl acetate. We find here that far less toluene is included in Cu3(BTC)2 than either MeCN and MeOH, which are adsorbed in the largest quantities for the guests investigated here. The response of the framework to guest adsorption is more complex than a linear relationship to the guest quantity.

elements.content: The SQUEEZE calculations imply the following order of adsorption quantities of noncoordinated guests in the pores: MeCN > 1-PrOH > 2-PrOH > MeOH > EtOH > hexane ≈ toluene > THF > cyclohexane. A comparison of the number of coordinated guests with the number of guests in the pores indicates that guests that fully occupied all Cu coordination sites (Table ), such as THF, may block further access of these guests to the remaining framework pores.
elements.clean_text: The SQUEEZE calculations imply the following order of adsorption quantities of noncoordinated guests in the pores: MeCN > 1-PrOH > 2-PrOH > MeOH > EtOH > hexane ~ toluene > THF > cyclohexane. A comparison of the number of coordinated guests with the number of guests in the pores indicates that guests that fully occupied all Cu coordination sites (Table ), such as THF, may block further access of these guests to the remaining framework pores.

elements.content: The volume available per noncoordinated guest molecule can be estimated from the solvent-accessible volume per unit cell, as determined from execution of the PLATON/SQUEEZE and PLATON/SOLV routines using the models for the SCXRD data that include coordinated guests (see , Table S4), and the number of noncoordinated guests per unit cell (Table ). A comparison of the volume available to each guest molecule using the molecular volume of the guest in the liquid state can be used as a gauge of the effects of guest confinement in Cu3(BTC)2. The volume available to guests are underestimated where the coordinated guest is partially occupied, as the SQUEEZE routine assumes full occupation and we use the largest coordinated guest where coordination of both H2O and guest molecules coexist. Despite this underestimation, the space available per guest in Cu3(BTC)2 is significantly larger than their molecular volume in their pure, liquid state (as calculated from the density of the pure liquid), and so we do not expect confinement effects for the guests in the Cu3(BTC)2 pores. It is important to note that these observations are made using SCXRD data collected over a 4 h period and that weakly interacting guests may be lost during the data collection.

elements.content: Gravimetric adsorption isotherms for H2O, MeOH, EtOH, 1- and 2-PrOH, benzene, cyclohexane, toluene, and methylcyclohexane are presented in Figure . The number of guests in the micropores of Cu3(BTC)2 was estimated at 0.3 of the saturation pressure (P 0) from the gravimetric adsorption isotherms (Table ). The available void space per guest molecule was calculated, based on a total calculated void space of 785 Å3 per formula unit (see Table S4 in ). In Table , this is compared to the volume occupied by each molecule in its liquid form. A close correlation is observed for the alcohols, while a greater deviation is observed for the larger cyclic hydrocarbons, which will not pack as well in the pores and are too big to occupy Pore C. These results generally indicate that the uptake of hydrocarbon guests is influenced strongly by entropic effects, consistent with the lack of π–π interactions indicated by the SCXRD data. More toluene was adsorbed than cyclohexane, consistent with the findings of the SCXRD data (Table ) and is attributed to differences in molecular size and not π–π interactions. There is no indication of any effect of confinement of these molecules in Cu3(BTC)2, such as previously observed for benzene adsorbed in the pores of the zeolite ZSM-5, where the density of benzene was between that of the bulk-liquid and a solid-like phase.

Gravimetrically Measured Uptake

Gravimetric adsorption isotherms for H2O, MeOH, EtOH, 1- and 2-PrOH, benzene, cyclohexane, toluene, and methylcyclohexane are presented in Figure . The number of guests in the micropores of Cu3(BTC)2 was estimated at 0.3 of the saturation pressure (P 0) from the gravimetric adsorption isotherms (Table ). The available void space per guest molecule was calculated, based on a total calculated void space of 785 Å3 per formula unit (see Table S4 in ). In Table , this is compared to the volume occupied by each molecule in its liquid form. A close correlation is observed for the alcohols, while a greater deviation is observed for the larger cyclic hydrocarbons, which will not pack as well in the pores and are too big to occupy Pore C. These results generally indicate that the uptake of hydrocarbon guests is influenced strongly by entropic effects, consistent with the lack of π-π interactions indicated by the SCXRD data. More toluene was adsorbed than cyclohexane, consistent with the findings of the SCXRD data (Table ) and is attributed to differences in molecular size and not π-π interactions. There is no indication of any effect of confinement of these molecules in Cu3(BTC)2, such as previously observed for benzene adsorbed in the pores of the zeolite ZSM-5, where the density of benzene was between that of the bulk-liquid and a solid-like phase.

Derived from desorption leg of isotherm.

The isotherms for the nonpolar, cyclic molecules (Figure b) are typical type I, with a relatively large uptake at lower partial pressures and further uptake at higher pressures. The initial stage of adsorption is attributed to micropore filling, while further uptake at higher pressures is attributed to phenomena including the formation of a multilayer on the outer surface, filling of any meso- or macroporous defects in the crystals, condensation in spaces between the particles, and increasing guest packing within the micropores, likely occurring in that order.

elements.content: In the case of cyclohexane adsorption, approximately 3 guest molecules per formula unit are rapidly adsorbed at low pressures (up to 0.03 P 0), but thereafter adsorption kinetics were significantly slower and equilibrium was not reached after 90 min at constant pressure; see shaded data points in Figure . Cyclohexane desorption kinetics were faster than for adsorption and equilibrium was achieved for each point. The slow adsorption kinetics are, at least partly, responsible for the large hysteresis in the isotherm, which was reproduced in a repeat measurement. The lattice contraction upon cyclohexane adsorption, revealed by the SCXRD data, is a possible contributor to this effect.

Solid markers are adsorption, shaded (for cyclohexane adsorption only) are nonequilibrium recorded points, and open markers are desorption.

elements.content: The adsorption isotherms for the smaller, polar alcohols (Figure a) are more complex, but can also be classed as variants of type I. This is consistent with the progressive filling of the smallest pores that the guest molecules can fit into, again, where entropic effects play a significant role in the uptake behavior. These isotherms are consistent with those recently reported for small polar molecules. The adsorption isotherms for MeOH and EtOH show significant enthalpic effects, with two steps at low pressure that suggest two classes of adsorption site with distinctly different enthalpies of adsorption. It has been shown above that MeOH and EtOH guests occupy the ordered sites 1 and 2, of which there are a total of 5 sites per formula unit, and which would be expected to provide the highest enthalpy of adsorption. The point at which these sites are fully occupied correlates roughly with the end of the first adsorption step in both isotherms (5–6 guests per formula unit). Notably, such enthalpic effects are not reflected in total uptake, with further guests (approximately 6 methanol or 3 ethanol guests per formula unit) located in sites with lower enthalpy of adsorption, either in the aromatic Pore A, or crystallographically disordered in other locations within the pores. A comparison of Table with the crystallographic results shows that, as for MeOH and EtOH, in all cases considerably more guests are adsorbed than can be located in the identified adsorption sites. The prevalence of entropic effects for molecular packing at higher concentrations, where enthalpic effects are less important, is consistent in general with that observed for metal organic frameworks with similar pore chemistry.

This is consistent with the progressive filling of the smallest pores that the guest molecules can fit into, again, where entropic effects play a significant role in the uptake behavior. These isotherms are consistent with those recently reported for small polar molecules. The adsorption isotherms for MeOH and EtOH show significant enthalpic effects, with two steps at low pressure that suggest two classes of adsorption site with distinctly different enthalpies of adsorption. It has been shown above that MeOH and EtOH guests occupy the ordered sites 1 and 2, of which there are a total of 5 sites per formula unit, and which would be expected to provide the highest enthalpy of adsorption. The point at which these sites are fully occupied correlates roughly with the end of the first adsorption step in both isotherms (5-6 guests per formula unit). Notably, such enthalpic effects are not reflected in total uptake, with further guests (approximately 6 methanol or 3 ethanol guests per formula unit) located in sites with lower enthalpy of adsorption, either in the aromatic Pore A, or crystallographically disordered in other locations within the pores. A comparison of Table  with the crystallographic results shows that, as for MeOH and EtOH, in all cases considerably more guests are adsorbed than can be located in the identified adsorption sites. The prevalence of entropic effects for molecular packing at higher concentrations, where enthalpic effects are less important, is consistent in general with that observed for metal organic frameworks with similar pore chemistry.

elements.content: The structure of the nanoporous framework Cu3(BTC)2 was studied with guests including the polar protic water and small-molecule alcohols methanol, ethanol, 1-propanol, and 2-propanol, as well as polar aprotic guests including acetonitrile and tetrahydrofuran. Nonpolar guests were also included in this series, such as the alkanes cyclohexane and hexane, and aromatic toluene. A strong correlation was noted between guest size and shape and its location, and Fourier-difference methods revealed strong enthalpic effects where guests reside in the smallest pores they are able to fit in. Small guests, both hydrophilic and lipophilic, adsorb favorably into the smallest pore of Cu3(BTC)2, with their number depending on guest size and their location being influenced both by guest−guest interactions and by competition between hydrogen-bonding interactions at the apertures of the pore and lipophilic interactions within the pore. Gravimetric vapor adsorption measurements for benzene, toluene, cyclohexane, and methylcyclohexane corroborated the SCXRD findings, with a near linear relationship between guest size and adsorption quantity.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The structure of the nanoporous framework Cu3(BTC)2 was studied with guests including the polar protic water and small-molecule alcohols methanol, ethanol, 1-propanol, and 2-propanol, as well as polar aprotic guests including acetonitrile and tetrahydrofuran. Nonpolar guests were also included in this series, such as the alkanes cyclohexane and hexane, and aromatic toluene. A strong correlation was noted between guest size and shape and its location, and Fourier-difference methods revealed strong enthalpic effects where guests reside in the smallest pores they are able to fit in. Small guests, both hydrophilic and lipophilic, adsorb favorably into the smallest pore of Cu3(BTC)2, with their number depending on guest size and their location being influenced both by guest-guest interactions and by competition between hydrogen-bonding interactions at the apertures of the pore and lipophilic interactions within the pore. Gravimetric vapor adsorption measurements for benzene, toluene, cyclohexane, and methylcyclohexane corroborated the SCXRD findings, with a near linear relationship between guest size and adsorption quantity.

elements.content: A complex structural response of the framework to guest adsorption was observed. The coordinatively unsaturated Cu sites attract guests with donor electrons, and coordination at this site was found subject to space constraints and flexibility of the guest molecule. Guest coordination at the Cu site results in an increase in the Cu···Cu length of the dinuclear paddlewheel unit. The unit cell is found to be smallest for the noncoordinating guest species and, in the case of cyclohexane, smaller than for the guest-free framework.
elements.clean_text: A complex structural response of the framework to guest adsorption was observed. The coordinatively unsaturated Cu sites attract guests with donor electrons, and coordination at this site was found subject to space constraints and flexibility of the guest molecule. Guest coordination at the Cu site results in an increase in the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu length of the dinuclear paddlewheel unit. The unit cell is found to be smallest for the noncoordinating guest species and, in the case of cyclohexane, smaller than for the guest-free framework.

elements.content: Our in situ structural analyses of the adsorption of a range of different guests into a single crystal has delivered a detailed structural understanding in the adsorption behaviors of these guests, that overall are influenced strongly by thermodynamic effects (both enthalpic and entropic), as well as interpore steric (size-exclusion) effects. This detailed understanding also highlights the broad range of applications for Cu3(BTC)2 and nanoporous metal–organic framework materials in general, including separations, catalysis, and gas storage.

This detailed understanding also highlights the broad range of applications for Cu3(BTC)2 and nanoporous metal-organic framework materials in general, including separations, catalysis, and gas storage.

cln_elements.content:
All chemicals were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich at 99% purity. Liquid guests for vapor adsorption were purified overnight with molecular sieves and calcium chloride. Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3·xH2O was synthesized by the addition of 0.700 mol of Cu­(NO3)2·6H2O in 6 mL of H2O to 0.03510 mol of H3BTC dispersed by sonication in 6 mL of ethanol. The mixture was stirred for 20 min, transferred into a 20 mL Teflon insert, placed in a Parr solvothermal bomb and heated to 95 °C for 18 h, and then cooled to room temperature over 8 h. Blue crystals were obtained by filtering, washing with deionized water, and air-drying. A single crystal was isolated for the SCXRD experiments. The remaining crystals were separated from a secondary product by alternative washing and sonication in methanol, a process involving four repeats with two washes performed at 50 °C. The product of pure blue crystals was air-dried and used for gravimetric vapor adsorption measurements.

Vapor Adsorption Isotherms

Gravimetric vapor adsorption experiments were performed using an IGA-002 from Hiden Isochema. Approximately 84 mg of powder Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3·x(H2O) was heated to 200 °C under vacuum (<10–5 mbar) for 9 h (forming Cu3(BTC)2) and cooled to 30 °C. Vapor adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured at 30 °C for MeOH, EtOH, 1-PrOH, 2-PrOH, benzene, cyclohexane, toluene, and methylcyclohexane at pressures up to 0.9 of saturation pressure (P 0). At each pressure the sample weight was monitored until equilibrium mass was achieved, or, in the case of cyclohexane, for 90 min. Reported masses are corrected for buoyancy of the sample and the balance. Adsorption isotherms of THF and MeCN were not measured because of incompatibility with the seals on the instrument.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Preparation of Cu3(BTC)2 and Guests

All chemicals were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich at 99% purity. Liquid guests for vapor adsorption were purified overnight with molecular sieves and calcium chloride. Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3⋅xH2O was synthesized by the addition of 0.700 mol of Cu(NO3)2⋅6H2O in 6 mL of H2O to 0.03510 mol of H3BTC dispersed by sonication in 6 mL of ethanol. The mixture was stirred for 20 min, transferred into a 20 mL Teflon insert, placed in a Parr solvothermal bomb and heated to 95 °C for 18 h, and then cooled to room temperature over 8 h. Blue crystals were obtained by filtering, washing with deionized water, and air-drying. A single crystal was isolated for the SCXRD experiments. The remaining crystals were separated from a secondary product by alternative washing and sonication in methanol, a process involving four repeats with two washes performed at 50 °C. The product of pure blue crystals was air-dried and used for gravimetric vapor adsorption measurements.

Vapor Adsorption Isotherms

Gravimetric vapor adsorption experiments were performed using an IGA-002 from Hiden Isochema. Approximately 84 mg of powder Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3⋅x(H2O) was heated to 200 °C under vacuum (<10-5 mbar) for 9 h (forming Cu3(BTC)2) and cooled to 30 °C. Vapor adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured at 30 °C for MeOH, EtOH, 1-PrOH, 2-PrOH, benzene, cyclohexane, toluene, and methylcyclohexane at pressures up to 0.9 of saturation pressure (P 0). At each pressure the sample weight was monitored until equilibrium mass was achieved, or, in the case of cyclohexane, for 90 min. Reported masses are corrected for buoyancy of the sample and the balance. Adsorption isotherms of THF and MeCN were not measured because of incompatibility with the seals on the instrument.
